title: FirstFT: Chinese economic growth slows
text:
China's gross domestic product grew at its slowest pace in 18 months in the fourth quarter as the government grapples with a slowdown in the crucially important property sector and tries to eradicate all coronavirus cases.

Gross domestic product expanded 4 per cent year on year, data from the National Bureau of Statistics revealed today, exceeding economists' forecasts but short of the 6.5 per cent growth over the same period in 2020.

The People's Bank of China also cut an important lending rate for the first time since April 2020, adding to a series of easing measures over recent months that have coincided with a property slowdown and restrictions to curb the spread of coronavirus.

The data and policy move indicated a continuing loss of momentum across China's economy, which recovered from the initial impact of the virus far more quickly than other big economies but has struggled to maintain its pre-pandemic growth rate over the past year.

Five more stories in the news

1. Credit Suisse chair resigns over Covid breaches António Horta-Osório has resigned as chair of Credit Suisse after a board investigation found that he had breached coronavirus quarantine rules more than once. “I regret that a number of my personal actions have led to difficulties for the bank and compromised my ability to represent the bank internally and externally,” Horta-Osório said in a statement last night.

2. Unilever defends £50bn bid for GSK consumer health unit The maker of Dove soap, Hellmann's mayonnaise and Domestos bleach has defended its £50bn bid for the consumer health unit of GlaxoSmithKline. The ambitious bid, unveiled over the weekend, drew scepticism from some analysts and sent the group's shares down 6 per cent in morning trading in London.

3. Top performing hedge funds of 2021 Large profits at Ken Griffin's Citadel and Sir Christopher Hohn's TCI made them among the best-performing hedge fund managers of last year. Izzy Englander's Millennium Management and Paul Singer's Elliott Management were also on the list, compiled by LCH Investments.

4. Macau casino shares rally The shares of casino operators with operations in Macau shot higher today after officials said they would maintain the number of licences available to gaming operators in the Chinese territory, ending years of uncertainty for US companies such as Sands China, MGM China and Wynn Macau.

5. JPMorgan plots ‘astonishing' $12bn tech spend The largest lender on Wall Street said it planned to dramatically increase spending on technology and talent to ward off the threat posed by new fintech companies. But the prospect of rising costs stirred investor worries about US bank earnings this year.

Coronavirus digest

  • Albert Bourla, Pfizer's chief executive, has predicted that the world will soon be able to return to “normal”, helped in part by products made by the US pharmaceuticals group.

  • Novak Djokovic left Australia on Sunday night after losing his bid to overturn the government's deportation order over his vaccination status.

  • Across the world, companies are struggling with how to approach worker vaccinations.

  • Hong Kong has “no definitive timeline” for lifting tough restrictions on international borders this year, a top official told the Financial Times.

The day ahead

Davos A special address by Chinese president Xi Jinping kicks off this year's virtual plenaries of the World Economic Forum. Also due to speak today are Indian prime minister Narendra Modi and UN secretary-general António Guterres.

Martin Luther King Day Bond and equity markets will be closed in the US for a public holiday.

What else we're reading

Has Sony become the entertainment group it always wanted to be? For years Sony either created or bought the right instruments to achieve its goal of becoming the world's most fully integrated entertainment company. But, according to critics, the $157bn Japanese company could never quite make the orchestra play in harmony. That now appears to be changing.

Leon Black targets New York elite in fight against rape claim The legal battle between Leon Black and his former mistress Guzel Ganieva has drawn in at least half a dozen law firms and threatens to embroil other wealthy figures in the worlds of finance and sport as the billionaire financier demands access to private records involving some of New York's most prominent businessmen.

How serious is Vladimir Putin about launching a major Ukraine offensive? If Russia ever wanted to renew its invasion of Ukraine, all signs point to that moment being now. This interactive graphic from our visual storytelling team and Max Seddon in Moscow explores the key reasons why.

What the Royal Family could learn from Apple Never mind the Queen's platinum anniversary next month; another epoch-defining figure is turning 15. While Apple clearly has some way to go to match the House of Windsor for jubilee planning, the royals could also learn a lot about product refreshes, writes Robert Shrimsley.

Why blaming your staff publicly is always a cheap shot There are few leadership moves more likely to make someone look like an “arsehole”, to quote the Australian television presenters who were caught attacking Novak Djokovic off-air, than publicly blaming your staff. Andrew Hill draws the lessons for managers from the tennis star's recent behaviour.
